reviews.review_text: In overall, everything about this game is awesome. Controls are smooth, gameplay is fast, decent graphics and sounds, the time-control spell makes this game particular. In my opinion, the story is a bit lame, but I do not really care, I forget it when I swing my swords in every directions :P. Collectibles are very easy to find during your walkthrought because maps are not that large, so no time wasted for that, just make sure to use compass. Great game to smash everything moving.

Fun action adventure that is deeper and more varied than it appears on the surface and has fun use of layered time to amplify combat power and solve problems.  Not sure worth $30 but I got in bundle cheap, worth it if on sale with good discount

Wow!!! Even by 2012 I thought it was impossible to innovate a hack and slash adventure game. I love the genre, but I just like the colors and combo strategy, I thought God of War covered the good stuff. And then I found this. Another lost gem that faded into non-existence because it's not a major AAA developer. Let me explain myself...  The best part about this is the time warp system. This is TOO FREAKING COOL! I'd suggest buying this game JUST to experience this mechanic. It's difficult to be innovative in modern gaming, so it's possible it had been done before and I just missed it, but either way it is incredibly fun. Basically you can reverse time in fairly short increments, but your 'past avatar' will still exist doing what you just did while your 'present avatar' is free to do whatever. You can make several of these avatars at once to fight alongside you or help you solve puzzles. It's a bit confusing at first, but once you get the hang of it you can't wait to use it again.   How it works is say you have a group of 3 enemies. You can take out your gun and blast away for 5 seconds at one of them while they charge you. Reverse 6 seconds. Your past avatar will now be there shooting at that same enemy. So now you have a few choices. You can use your present avatar to keep shooting at the same enemy, reverse time 6ish seconds again, shoot at that enemy, repeat however many times you want, and then suddenly have 5+ people blasting this enemy away in 2 seconds. Or you can use another avatar to shoot a second enemy, making them stumble or holding them back. Now you have 2+ avatars distracting two enemies, so you can charge in with your main avatar using swords and melee on the third. To top it off, after, say, 3 seconds of meleeing that third mob, you can reverse 4ish seconds, and now you'll have both your past and present avatar wailing away at this mob. Repeat however many times you want. You now effectively have 4+ warriors on the battlefield attacking at the same time, and even though the process took place over 20 seconds, once you reverse to the very start of the battle and continue time, all 3 mobs will drop dead in an instant.  It's awesome.  The next best thing are the puzzles. FINALLY I find another game with unique puzzles that actually make you think without being outrageously difficult just for the sake of being difficult. And it's none of the usual 'do this kind of puzzle once then use it a bunch more times.' Instead, they draw elements from previous puzzles but add a twist or two to keep it fresh. I still haven't beaten it, but as of now I've encountered 3 different 'types' of puzzles and each one has been expanded upon later in the 'level' to make it feel new. Well done.  The next best thing is the graphics. Graphics are normally the least of my worries and something I'll glance at, appreciate, and move on. But considering the time period and developer, this game is INCREDIBLE! It absolutely stands up to some of today's games but is beautifully optimized. It baffles me how a game from 2012 can look, and more importantly run, 1000% smoother than a game from 2015.  Third I'll go with the boss fights. Again, FINALLY a game that has unique bosses that, again, require you to think and stay focused. Not every single one, some are the typical slash away without getting hit, but others do require specific strategies. And hey the strategies aren't always necessary either. You CAN slash away at this boss for an incredibly difficult 20 minutes, but if you learn how to exploit weaknesses, you can take them down in a few attack runs.  Next would be the combat. Not the most innovative aspect of the game, but still a tried and true method that is just as fun as it always is. It starts off pretty generic, but once you start unlocking combos it exponentially increases the fun and some are unique enough to make Blades of Time stand out amongst its God of War and Dynasty Warrior peers. And this is where the time warp mechanic comes in. Just like I was saying with the puzzles, it takes an old mechanic and makes it new again. It's also a good balance between simple and difficult. You cannot just stand there and spam left mouse button. You will die. Though you don't necessarily have to be constantly in motion 100% of the time either...in a good way. You CAN be and it makes it that much more fun, but it isn't completely necessary, which I prefer. I like to jump around a bit and get in hits here and there, then wail away at a single enemy, then jump around a bit more.  However I'll finish off with the voice acting and story. To be fair I actually do enjoy the storyline. Maybe it's not pulitzer prize winning, but it is somewhat unique compared to most fantasy games. Unfortunately, as others have noted, the voice acting is horrendous. I actually laugh pretty much any time anyone says anything because it feels so...fake and out of place. You can tell this is where they cut the budget from. If you've ever played an Oblivion or Skyrim mod where the creator did their own voice acting...it's kind of like that. Just awkward with mediocre writing where it's almost difficult to actually pay attention to what they're saying and not how they're saying it.  But overall I recommend this game to anyone who likes action games, and DEFINITELY anyone who loves hack and slash games. I am actually quite stingy with prices, so t's difficult to say if it's worth $25. I almost NEVER spend more than $15 on a game. Though $25 on Steam for a 4 year old game is somewhat of a testament to the game's quality. However if it's on sale under $15 I wouldn't even hesitate to add it to your cart. If that extra $10 isn't a big deal to your wallet, then yeah I'll definitely give the go ahead for $25.  Blades of Steel  8/10a  And if you're wondering, I actually got it in one of those '10 Premium Steam Keys' for $1.12 at a certain third party retailer site. I gotta say I got some pretty good games in those bundles, I'd say it's worth getting 1 or 2 if you're looking for something new to try.

3rd person, action, adventure, hack and slash game.  In this game you play as female warrior - treasure hunter. You are thrown into the game pretty much right after cinematic intro, with not much explanation on what happened before it. Game doesn't have that great of a story, but somewhat compensates with decent, challenging combat and easy on the eyes main heroine.  Visuals are average with not that great texture quality and effects. Voice acting is decent enough. Animation quality is not that great, and there is a lot of clipping, skewing and stretching in the combat animations. Level and environment design is good, though low resolution textures is an issue. Apart from that, game is fun little hack and slash experience, with addition to few magic spells and rewind time abillity.  Character customization available through melee and ranged weapons, costumes and miscellaneous jewelry items, that you get from chests you find. If it's cheap or on discount, get it.

When I first started this game, I hated every character and loved the combat. I thought the story was incredibly stupid and I was kind of surprised a game like this even had a story. It's the kind of game where every female character looks like they just came out of a 14 year old boy's wet dream. Ayumi isn't even the worst offender of this!  Shockingly enough, the characters evolved such that I actually *liked* them- each main character received enough characterization to become real, likeable, *people*, rather than the walking videogame cliches they look like (ridiculously musclebound man, ridiculously over sexualized women). This astounded me; I was not expecting to have anything but contempt for the game's seemingly pathetic attempt at story. The main plot, too, evolves into something worthwhile. The biggest problem this game has is probably the fact that the story and characters are overwhelmingly generic for the first half of the game.... but it does metamorphose into something unique towards the end. Well, the characters do; the story is largely generic still but there are several key plot points that separate it from the rest.  Unfortunately what did not evolve over time was the combat. As far as I know there are no combos to learn besides the very limited set you start out with. One of the combos brings you up into the air as you swing your sword about wildly, *but there are never ever any enemies that will be in the air with you*. What ends up happening is a lengthy animation of you swinging your sword in the air for 5 seconds while all the enemies wait for you to return to the ground. This happens automatically when you jump and attack- so if you need to jump over to an enemy *quickly* and attack him, unless you're very careful you might accidentally start that useless combo and it will prevent you from doing time sensitive things (there is no way to stop once started). I feel like I missed out on a mechanic or two though- you can lock onto enemies and dash at them, but 90% of the time the game bugs out and the dash is in slow motion and you never even reach the enemy. Then I read something about hanging from enemies in midair and hitting them with your sword. Huh. The most I was ever able to do was slide off them like they were covered in motor oil. You gain the ability to use fire, ice and generic projectiles very early on and then (with one exception) from there on out, all upgrades are minor and passive (for example, you might gain the ability to do more damage by using fire on someone who is frozen. No expanded gameplay, just ways to optimize damage). I started out really loving the combat, but it gets very old very fast. And it's very buggy. The entire game is buggy actually. Luckily you can usually fix everything by reloading the last checkpoint, but if your checkpoint is before a particularly challenging battle, that can be frustrating.  Another major problem with this game is there are too many different mechanics. It feels like I'm playing a very long demo of hundreds of different games. Yes, the combat is boring, but constantly changing the rules of the world is not the way to fix that. At one point you gain wings and can fly, and I don't even think it is explained... then you lose your wings shortly after, also unexplained. I found out by jumping off a cliff and falling to my death. At one point you are given a gun which you are required to use; if you kill the enemies without the gun, they keep regenerating indefinitely, and this is *not explained*. It was pretty obvious I had to use the gun to kill them, but I couldn't quite figure out how, and I couldn't proceed by killing them normally. The biggest problem was the stupid jump combo- you had to freeze the enemy with the gun, then drop the gun and hit them before they thawed, except I would always activate that useless combo and never get to them in time. The time rewind itself is also problematic. For example, the ability is not explained at all. You are told that you have it, then you need to figure out how it works, which is a process that will take the rest of the game. But the game arbitrarily changes the way it works and often doesn't even let you use it! How can you learn to use it if it keeps alternating between different rule sets and often isn't even available to use? So far what I *think* happens with the standard set of rules is; any time clones of you will disappear if the main you alters enough variables in the past. So if you go back in time and get an enemy to follow the current you instead of the past you, the past you just disappears. Which is a problem because most of the time the point of time rewind is to distract enemies- but they mostly seem interested in *you*, not your past clones, which makes them all vanish, which makes the game frustrating. OK, so I understand that, I'll try to use it against this boss now that I'm a little better with it. Oh wait, you can't. Why? Because. Time rewind is not available to you for nearly *every single boss*. Then, some of the larger enemies require that you use it, but the way it works is completely different for those enemies. In one case- there's a quick time event which you need to do twice at the same time. Cool right? Not really. You do it once, you rewind time and if you don't press the button *immediately*, you lost your shot at it and you need to spend 5 more minutes weakening the enemy again. To reiterate- you can't just go back in time and wait for the opportunity to use the quick time event going forward in time, you have to hit the quick time event whilst going backwards in time.. because for some reason your clone disappears in this particular context (you can't make time rewind clones). Then, on the giant worm boss, you can make time rewind clones but the moment you do the boss just retreats, changing variables and erasing all your clones immediately. The logistics of this time rewind thing is complicated enough without all the arbitrary exceptions and changes.   I can't decide if I like this game or not. On the one hand, there are unique gameplay and story elements that are definitely worth experiencing; there is nothing else like it. On the other hand, the game doesn't respect itself enough to expand upon the more interesting elements and instead chooses to try 100 different things, which all collapse into one incoherent mess of a game. I suppose I recommend this game only because the length is short enough that you can actually complete it before being fed up with its many issues, and I think it is worth at least $10, so pick it up in the next sale.

The only cons I see is that You never know when there is a CHECKPOINT, so it's hard to stop playing and resume the next day. But checkpoints were reasonably set up, so it made this game a little bit easier. I do not agree with someone who said that story is not deep. Story was quite interesting, and I really enjoyed it.

This game is a lot of fun and is not to be taken seriously. The voice acting is atrocious, full of unintentional comedy. It is a God of War clone with a second string Lara Croft in the lead complete with English accent (or maybe Australian? either way terrible and inconsistent and hilarious.) Story is disjointed and incoherent, but still fun. It's a B-movie in a game with high production standards. Give it a try if you can find it for cheap.

Mindless fun with a hot chick, what more can you ask for? This game is a weird mix between Prince of Persia and Devil May Cry. There's plenty of hack&slash fun to be had but the campaign is repetitive, the story laughable and there's no replay value once you are done with it. Yet the time rewind mechanic is a highlight with enough room for experimentation. Overall this game is worth buying if you find it at a discount.

I picked this game up in a really cheap Humblr Bundle some time back and have been really pleasantly surprised by just how good it is. The hack and slash game play is incredibly fun when slicing down groups of enemies with duel blades and elemental abilities that are gained and upgraded throughout the game, and the graphics make for a really beautiful world with many different areas. The stories nothign special in my opinion and is extremely linear but it's still very enjoying without paying too much attention to it and there are a few moments where the game doesn't properly exdplain what needs doing to get past or to defeat a certain enemy but a quick look at a walk through can get you straight back into hacking and slashing the crap out of everything again in no time!   I personally wouldn't pay full price for this game myself, but if you see it on sale and enjoy fast paced hack and slash games then you should definitely give it a go!

God Of War clone with time rewinding mechanics. That's how I would explain this game to you. The rewinding mechanics allows you to work with your clone(s) to finish off enemies and bosses or solve puzzles. The puzzle aspect doesn't really fit the game, but hey, it works I guess. Think 'standing on switches' and things like that.  Then there's the weapon and ability upgrading which is pretty extensive. The graphics are pretty good; I was actually surprised by how good it looked in motion. Your main character looks great (but forgettable), with the ponytails and all (woohoo, <3 ponytails !). The voice acting, however, is a bit cheesy. Mmyeah, that was to be expected I guess. But since I'm not really into the mindless action these games offer (I do enjoy them from time to time) I stopped before finishing it. No, I'm not ashamed of it. It's just not my cup of tea. In the end Blades Of Time turned out to be a very decent game, so if you're into God Of War(-like games) you might enjoy it.  [Rating: 70/100]

Blades of Time is a better game than X-Blades, but not by much. The game knows it has a good idea because it abuses the time feature trick a bit too much, and like a kid wanting attention, you’ll just get fed up with it being in your face all the time. I did have fun with the game – there’s something about it that made me enjoy just hacking down some fools with my clones in fancy fashion, even if the rest of the combat is a little flat and basic. In the end though, all the problems pull it down and make Blades of Time a game that can be fun to play at times, but nothing more. If you don’t mind that, you might be one of the people that Ayumi is just looking for, because I can’t see her finding many fans with her latest treasure hunt.

Such an awesomely bad game, in the best way possible. The plot, writing, and voice acting are absolutely terrible. It's kind of like when you watch a bad movie with your friends just to make fun of it the whole time. Pretty much exactly like House of the Dead 1 and 2 in terms of a good bad game.  The actual gameplay is pretty good. Kind of reminds me of the spam of Dynasty Warriors in the setting of Devil May Cry little level arenas. It also has some Prince of Persia style time rewind puzzles. It even has a little FPS stance you can switch to and just headshot all the things, and a cute little reload cancel quick switch to go with it. The visuals aren't too shabby either, pretty nice actually. The graphics do seem a bit dated, and it does feel like this game is years older than it actually it, but it was still a pretty nice bad game. There is an Outbreak mode too, which is basically DoTa style hack and slash, but good luck finding a pug game as multiplayer is basically dead.  Very solid buy for the lulz. Kind of reminds me of Prototype 2 in terms of good gameplay, horrible characters/voices/story. Decent gameplay, somewhat beautiful visuals, and all the terrible plot, writing, and voice acting you can enjoy making fun of the whole way through.

Blades of Time the successor to X-Blades and awful incomplete hack and slash that will amuse you for maybe 3 bosses before you realize how broken and unfinished the game is. Back to BoT, similar to X-Blades it feels like an older game that doesn't exactly hold your hand and thrusts you out into the world of unknown.  You'll quicky catch on that there are no combos just button mashing and learning to dodge and abuse your time rewind ability.In this factor the game gets better as you progress and get amazingly cool abilities to fight off even more challenging monsters.I played on hardmode without realizing you could go to normal mode and didn't repeat a level more than 5 times because of the usually good check points.  The mechanics overall are good and you run into some fun, interesting, and also annoying puzzles. They also have treasure chests throughout the levels that reward loot.Though I've only gotten a total of 2 swords through my entire first play through.One at the very beginning of the game from a chest, the other from the boss before the final boss.Considering there are a large amount of swords in the game it kind of makes you wonder.  This game is definitely not worth the retail price and you shouldn't buy it unless you find it on sale like I did for the ultimate edition($7.50) By the time you start to get some really cool abilities and you figure out how to use your abilities properly you realize you're practically done with the game and that there are some unpatched bugs that make doing the final boss annoying as all hell due to his mechanics.Thankfully there is a work around.  Overall I give it a 5.9/10 for a time waster mainly because some of the mobs don't even have a mechanic other than to make your life a living hell.

I found this game to be about average across the board. The combat is decent and the envirioments are pretty for its time and specs. If your a fan of the genre you will find a decent time here just dont expect too much from this game. For non genre players the game may seem a bit flat and too much of a clunky button masher. One important thing though is change the audio language to japanese or one of the others because the english voice acting is god awful and if you do miss the ocasional caption you wont be missing asnything worthwhile as the dialog is abysmal as well.  Main draws: fun time mechanic, bog standard hack n slash fun, decent visuals, decent controls Main gripes: God awful english and dialog, incoherent story, terrible shooting mechanic  Reminds me of: Tomb raider (style/presentation), Devil may cry (mechanics), Prince of Persia (mechanics)  For: People looking for a hack n slash game on the cheap to hold them over in between other games.  Price: Wait till on some super sale below 10 dollars.

Blades of Time is probably best compared to Darksiders and God of War; hordes of enemies ready to die, simple but smooth combat techniques. It delivers much more.   Although it has two difficulties, the game will adjust in subtle ways after loading from a save game, slowly increasing until it gives you a distinct advantage, however never feeling like it's belittleing you, just that the game is trying to keep the flow going.  It borrows an element from Prince of Persia, allowing you to rewind time, however this creates 'clones' of your actions, with the only limit being how many clones your computer can render until it crashes. There is something deeply satisfying about seeing a boss drop from full health to no health in a second or two thats not found elsewhere that I know of.  One last tidbit. This has to be the only game I've played (at least to memory) where as the female lead gets further into the game her clothes get less revealing, whilst still giving off a sexy vibe.

OK, so you're this xena warrior princess who lusts for treasure and glory, so you attack some magician guy and force him to let you into the 'dragonland,' where legendary treasure awaits. The story is, shall we say 'lacking'. The cutscenes and gameplay graphics are fine, but everything in this game feels like it was stretched vertically... like a widescreen film that was squeezed to fit a standard frame. I haven't played the game for long, but combat so far is not very challenging. It was entertaining at first, but the main character narrates her surrounding and the action as it happens. She literally will NOT SHUT UP (I got that JarJar Binks feeling). The environment is quarky too. Blades of Time is an action-adventure hack-and-slash video game.   It is a discount Devil May Cry/God of War but it doesn't mean it's a bad game. The plot is very simple, the voice acting of everyone but the protagonist is pretty good, there are a couple of collectibles, fun times with the Rewind ability. Has several puzzles and interesting boss battles. There's no Guard/Defense button but you may heal quite often so it's ok. Took me 'round 10 hours without DLC. Got it at a Humble Store sale.   Good: +Rewind ability. You can copy yourself multiple times and punish enemies. Some enemies/bosses in fact need you to abuse the Rewind. +The voiceacting from everyone but Ayumis is fairly nice.  +You can choose different weapons and accessories as you progress. They will give you different strengths. +The puzzles are simple yet need timing or some trial and error. +A pair of boss battles are interesting. The rest are blunt and direct.   Bad: -Her voiceacting. Even if she's strong willed and stubborn, I can't stand her voice.  -If you don't try different combos or don't use the Rewind much the combat turns very repetitive. -Sometimes gravity betrays you and you turn heavier than usual, giving you no chance to recover from a fall.  -The plot is simple. Adding a subplot or something would've been nice.  -The ending.   Overall is a decent game. Not worth full price but a good choice for a sale.

As many other reviews have already stated, this is a 'beat-em-up' in the vein of Devil May Cry or Bayonetta. Unfortunately, it cannot live up to that legacy. The story is not memorable (borderline terrible), the amount of times you're given the same information over and over becomes ridiculous, and odd pacing make it hard to appreciate any positive aspect of the game.  Graphically, it's decent enough to look at but not something to write home to Mom about. The controls are serviceable, but oftentimes I found myself targeting an enemy and falling to my death, or attempting to hit the button prompt and instead getting beaten to death by the enemy that shouldn't have been able to hit me in the first place.  And man, they really need to work on their character work. Supporting characters would show up with no introduction, yet we as the audience are supposed to understand who they are. None of the characters were intriguing, and the interaction and introduction of the characters was extremely sloppy.  If you can get past all of that, then you have a serviceable beat-em-up. However, if you have any others sitting in your backlog, think twice before picking this one up.  Final verdict: if you enjoy games where every single character is annoying and terribly written, bad guys that spout dialogue that is so muddled in post-processing that you need subtitles to just understand the (threadbare) storyline, and semi-janky controls then this might be up your alley!

FIrstly, I should state that I got the game for the price of $1 as part of a humble bundle. At that price I would recommend it. Otherwise unfortunately I would advise people to stay away from this hack and slash.  Pros: -Beatiful aesthetics and graphics(considering when it was made) -Combat feels smooth and responsive - Time rewind mechanic is inovative and offers a new element to the typical hack and slash  Cons: - The story is non existent - The voice acting and dialogue are one of the worst I have encountered - Puzzles are annoying and unimaginative (Excluding the desert level which i enjoyed) - The Time rewind mechanic is poorly implemented - Boss fights are poorly made with a few exceptions - Even though there is a good amount of different enemies it feels as if you are fighting the same two generic types each level - The skills and combo system is poorly made in comparison to games like Castlevania, Dante's Inferno, Nier and even Wolverine.  Overall, I would give this game a 5/10 and would thus not recommend it. If you are looking for a decent hack and slash game I can direct your attention towards Castlevania, Metal Gear Rising:Revengance and Prince of Persia: Warrior Within.

'Blades of Time', a 3rd person hack & slash in the manner of 'Devil May Cry', is a game where nothing feels quote right.  You are a scantily-clad blond treasure hunter named Ayumi (I guess the developers where watching watching/reading too many animes/mangas), who is transported to Dragonland (because magic) where there's untold treasure (because ancient legends), and of course, a warmongering Chaos demon (because ancient prophecy). And you are sort of in the middle of all this, and hack & slash your way through without true reasons.  Extremely crappy story aside, there's much wrong with this title.  First, the visuals. What seems a lush and vibrant world at first glance, is really just a stiff, brightly-colored jungle. Ayumi just clips through the greenery, the leaves and grass are mostly static. Dragonland felt like a colorful dead world. Character animations are stiff, too. What look like detailed models from afar are revealed to be really mediocre ones. But, this is a budget title, so the graphics issues are truly the least concern.  What is a huge issue are the gameplay and the controls.  Ayumi moves too fast. She jumps too high. Controlling her never feels alright. Precision jumping is almost impossible. Even walking narrow ledges is a challenge due to speedy movement. The enemies have no 'meat'. Ayumi's swords just sort of pas through them, and then they eventually fall down. The combo system is poor, and the melee deteriorates into mindless button mashing. The shooting part of combat seems tacked-on and minimally refined.  Add to all this the fact you have to constantly bear with Ayumi's babbling, presented via poor and annoying voice-work...  Ugh, There's much to quit 'Blades of Time', and very little to stick to it.
